posts.name: Jayden
posts.cooked: Heya again folks! We are currently writing a pid for our arm. We referenced team 1108 2023 robot code to create a trapezoidprofile pid and a feedforward. Looking through a few teams code, they use relative encoders. However, from my understanding absolute encoders allow you to have a set zero point. Since our starting position may vary throughout games, would we easily be able to use an absolute encoder instead. Sorry might be a dumb question. Here is our current code:

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked:
Using either relative or abs. encoders would be possible, BUT it is not a good idea to use relative encoders on something like this.

Referencing my team’s training materials, a good way to find out if you need a relative or abs. encoder is to look at the DOF of the mechanism: image 1249×714 105 KB

image 1249×714 105 KB

image 1249×714 105 KB

Screenshot 2024-03-08 143000 1260×704 161 KB

Screenshot 2024-03-08 143000 1260×704 161 KB

Screenshot 2024-03-08 143000 1260×704 161 KB

As you can see above, continuous DOFs, have an ir relevant position, and a relative encoder would work just fine, as you don’t need to know the exact spot of the DOF.

Meanwhile, Discrete DOFs, have a relevant position and, programs likely need to know their position relative to something else, (a known zero) other than the start/stop position of a relative encoder.

TL;DR Relative encoders are relative to their stop/start points (inside the encoder), while absolute encoders are relative to a known zero point, and would give you accurate measurements. Use an absolute encoder.

Also, limit switches for the forward and backwards limits would help

posts.name: Jayden
posts.cooked: Okay, thank you! Very nice diagrams btw

posts.name: Josh (he/him)
posts.cooked:
If you can consistently set up your mechanism physically every time you power up your robot, you wouldn’t necessarily need to use an absolute encoder to get consistent control results. That known starting position could be your 0, or whatever else you’d prefer that known position to be.

In general this might be a less robust approach than using an absolute encoder, and depending on the sensitivity of the mechanism to small variations in position and the repeatability of your setup process, may not be effective enough, but it can be done.

posts.name: Anderson Hall
posts.cooked: @moore_ryan made them, as well as more of our training materials

posts.name: Jayden
posts.cooked: Thank you for that explanation. Would you perhaps happen to have any code examples or even some documentation from you and your team? We would appreciate if we could be able to examine them. Thank you very much.

posts.name: Josh (he/him)
posts.cooked:
I can offer up our subsystem and command code from last season, though I freely admit we likely don’t have the best code practices to copy from:

We also don’t have any formal documentation, but I can discuss our setup last year where we utilized the relative encoder and a known starting position with the above code. Our intake, attached to the elevator, would rest on the ground while the robot was powered off and disabled. On powerup, the ground became our 0 position, and our heights for various actions were relative increases from there. On robot enable, the default command for the subsytem drove the elevator to its intake position to ensure it stayed off the ground at all other times.

posts.name: loafdog
posts.cooked:
I tried to look at the file you included in original post but it is gone.  I am looking at this file now 2024RobotCode/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ArmSubsystem.java at main · CyberTitan-Coders/2024RobotCode · GitHub I did not see any code to activate the right motor except in the stop method.  Maybe I missed something? If not, might want to make the right motor a follower of left.

You can use a relative encoder to control arm position.  There just has to be a way to zero or set the relative encoder to match the physical position of the arm when robot is powered on.  The absolute encoder remembers its position across power cycles.  When the robot starts set the relative encoder position to absolute encoder position.  Another way to do this is with limit switches.  When arm hits a limit switch set relative encoder.  It helps to have hard physical stops when resetting encoder as well.  Josh_Fox suggestion works fine too if you don’t have limit switches or absolute encoders.   But if robot is powered on with arm in unexpected position bad things can happen.

We use the relative encoder built into neo and spark max position pid to control the arm position.  And trapezoid profile to feed setpoint to position pid on spark max.   We use a rev absolute encoder to zero(reset) the relative encoder, it is connected to the roborio, not spark max.  You can see we do that here when robot code starts: Crescendo2024/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/arm/ArmIOSparkMax.java at fc537551e749293565f29ee46606b8248714ccc8 · DevilBotz2876/Crescendo2024 · GitHub We also use the absolute encoder to enforce high/low limits. Crescendo2024/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/arm/ArmSubsystem.java at fc537551e749293565f29ee46606b8248714ccc8 · DevilBotz2876/Crescendo2024 · GitHub
